awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Mechanistic Study of Radical Initiations for Aromatic Functionalization
awd_abstract_narration:
In this CAREER project, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics & Mechanisms B Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Ryan Baxter of the Department of Chemistry & Chemical Biology at the University of California, Merced is developing new strategies for initiating radical reactions through single-electron transfers.  Because one electron reactions (radical reactions) are traditionally viewed as highly reactive and difficult to control, the goal of this research is to better understand fundamental properties of radical initiations to engineer mild and user-friendly experimental protocols.  Many structures that can be accessed via radical chemistry are found in drugs, vitamins, materials and polymers, and so new strategies for radical initiation may have a positive impact on many fields of science that directly benefit society.  The project involves monitoring radical reactions in real-time to understand chemical behavior.  The resulting reaction data is used to develop educational materials for undergraduate organic chemistry laboratory and lecture courses. In addition, through industrial partnerships, volumes of authentic reaction data is collected and refined to develop a repository of undergraduate/graduate educational materials that are made available to educators throughout the Nation.   

Arenes and heteroarenes are common structures with many desirable materials.  Strategies for their rapid diversification are in demand. Radical carbon-hydrogen functionalization offers the ability to directly modify aromatic carbon hydrogen bonds via either nucleophilic or electrophilic processes, although uncontrolled reactivity is common to intermolecular processes.  This project involves two discrete aims to study fundamental physical properties that affect rates of radical initiation for synthetically important reactions.  The first focuses on developing catalyst systems that use silver ion, as an oxidant, and exogenous pyridine ligands in a novel way to control the rates of radical initiation for intermolecular nucleophilic functionalization of heteroarenes. Catalyst redox properties are studied electrochemically, and this data is correlated with global reaction rates to inform the development of optimum catalyst/oxidant systems.  The second aim involves the iron-catalyzed reduction of nitrogen-oxygen bonds to promote intermolecular radical amination of arenes through an electrophilic process.  The electronic properties of various nitrogen-radical precursors are examined to develop efficient strategies that combine mild initiation with reliable rates of initiation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Professor Ryan Baxter’s research at UC Merced, funded by the National Science Foundation’s (NSF) CAREER Award, focused on advancing the understanding of radical chemical reactions and their applications. The project achieved notable success in developing new chemical reactions, designing innovative materials, and creating educational tools to train the next generation of scientists. Their work addressed the NSF’s criteria for intellectual merit and broader impacts by contributing to fundamental science, interdisciplinary collaborations, and educational outreach.

Intellectual Merit: The research centered around developing novel methods for initiating and controlling radical reactions—chemical processes involving highly reactive molecules that are essential for creating complex materials, pharmaceuticals, and advanced organic compounds. One of the project’s key breakthroughs was the discovery of new ways to use halogen bonding to control radical reactions. Halogen bonding, a non-covalent interaction similar to hydrogen bonding, was shown to enhance the efficiency and selectivity of radical reactions such as aromatic bromination​. This finding opened new pathways for chemists to perform transformations that were previously difficult or required costly metal catalysts. 

Another major accomplishment was the creation of N-nitrososulfonamide reagents, which can be used to form to transfer the “NO” functional group under mild conditions. These reagents simplify the synthesis of complex molecules, allowing chemists to build new compounds with specific properties. For example, they were shown to facilitate the formation of important intermediates like nitroso and diazo compounds, which are often used in drug development​. Such innovations contribute to a deeper understanding of reaction mechanisms and provide new tools for synthetic organic chemistry.

Broader Impacts: Baxter’s research went beyond laboratory science by influencing fields such as material science and nanotechnology. His group collaborated with physicists and engineers to develop light-emitting organic molecules and electroactive materials. These materials have potential applications in solar energy harvesting, light-emitting diodes (LEDs), and advanced display technologies​. By connecting organic chemistry with real-world applications, Baxter’s work demonstrates how fundamental research can lead to new technologies that benefit society. 

Educationally, the project had a significant impact on training students and improving chemistry education. Baxter integrated his research into undergraduate courses, developing laboratory experiments that reflect the latest findings in radical chemistry. He also organized professional development workshops on science communication, which aimed to help students effectively share their research with both scientific and public audiences. This outreach effort equipped students with valuable skills for their careers and helped bridge the gap between advanced research and educational practices.

Overall, Professor Baxter’s project achieved its goals of enhancing the understanding of radical chemical reactions while creating broader impacts through interdisciplinary collaborations and educational innovation. His research has not only advanced the scientific community’s knowledge of chemical mechanisms but has also laid the groundwork for new technologies and contributed to the development of future chemists.
